editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

[There are three,] viz. three Per≈øons, which are pre≈øently after expre≈ø≈øed, [that beare witne≈ø≈øe in heaven,] viz. to the truth ≈øpoken of, v. 6. namely, that Christ came both by water and blood, both to ≈øanctifie and to ju≈øtifie, and to be a perfect Saviour of his people from their ≈øins, by taking away both the ≈øtaine and the guilt of them.

[And the Holy Gho≈øt,] The third Per≈øon of the Trinity, called the Spirit, the holy Spirit, or the Holy Gho≈øt: God (as God) is a Spirit, Joh. 4. 24. and ≈øo is holy; and therefore this appellation of Spirit and holy Spirit, or Holy Gho≈øt, belongs al≈øo to the Father, and to the Son, yet it is more peculiarly attributed, and in a manner appropriated to the third Per≈øon, why it is ≈øo, I will not now ≈øtand to inquire.

This therefore is the meaning of the words, and ≈øo much the phra≈øe imports, that the≈øe are e≈ø≈øentially and ≈øub≈øtantially one, that they are one e≈ø≈øence and one ≈øub≈øtance, one God: This Expo≈øition is agreeable to other places of Scripture, to the words them≈øelves, and is generally imbraced. From the words thus explicated, there ari≈øeth Doct. this Doctrine, That the Father, the Son and the Holy Gho≈øt, are three distinct Per≈øons, yet but one and the ≈øame God.

Fir≈øt, they are three dictinct Per≈øons, differing each from other; ≈øo that the Father is not the Son, nor the Holy Gho≈øt, neither is the Son the Holy Gho≈øt; they are clearly di≈øtingui≈øhed, Mat. 3. 16, 17. And Je≈øus, when he was baptized, went up ≈øtraitway out of the water, and loe the heavens were opened unto him, and he ≈øaw the Spirit of God de≈øcending like a Dove, and lighting upon him: And loe, a voyce from heaven, ≈øaying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well plea≈øed. Here we have the fir≈øt Per≈øon, the Father, who ≈øpake from heaven, as is plaine by tho≈øe words, My beloved Son: He who hath a ≈øon mu≈øt needs be a father. We have here al≈øo the ≈øecond Per≈øon, the Son, of whom the Father ≈øpake, and who is expre≈øly mentioned. And ≈øo al≈øo is the third Per≈øon, the Spirit, the holy Spirit, or Holy Gho≈øt, who came down in the likene≈ø≈øe of a Dove: All the≈øe three are here ≈øo de≈øcribed and ≈øet forth, as that they plainly appeare to be di≈øtinct each from other. So the di≈øtinction of the Father and the Son, is evident from that 1 Joh. 4. 9, 10. where it's ≈øaid, that God ≈øent his Son: by God there, mu≈øt needs be meant the Father, and the Per≈øon ≈øending mu≈øt needs be di≈øtinct from the Per≈øon ≈øent, ≈øo con≈øequently the Father and the Son are two dictinct Per≈øons: And by the ≈øame rea≈øon ≈øo are al≈øo the Father and the Holy Gho≈øt; for the Father ≈øends, the Holy Gho≈øt is ≈øent, The Holy Gho≈øt whom the Father will ≈øend, &c. div.p:

∆≤≈øe 1. Let not ≈øin therefore reign in your mortall body, Rom. 6. 12. The greate≈øt tyrants and oppre≈ø≈øours being in the grave, all their tyranny and oppre≈ø≈øion cea≈øeth. There the wicked cea≈øe from troubling, Joh. 3. 17. So we being in the ≈øen≈øe before expre≈ø≈øed, by way of analogy and re≈øemblance buried with Chri≈øt, ≈øin ≈øhall not have that power over us, as over the unregenerate. I ≈øay, not ≈øo, as over the unregenerate. But we mu≈øt not think that whiles we are here, we can be ≈øo conformed unto Chri≈øt, ≈øo dead and buried with him as to be without ≈øin, to be quite free from it. No, If we ≈øay that we have no ≈øin, we deceive our ≈øelves 1 Joh. 1. 8. In many things we offend all, Iam. 3. 2. But if we have the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt (And if any have not the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt, the ≈øame is none of his, Rom. 8. 9.) then we are ≈øo in a ≈øpirituall ≈øen≈øe dead and buried with Chri≈øt, as not to be under the reigning power of ≈øin, and the dominion of it. Sin ≈øhall not have dominion over you, for you are not under the Law but under grace, Rom. 6. 14.

Again, there is not the like rea≈øon of ≈øpirituall death and buriall, and of that which it corporall. For corporal death and buriall is fini≈øhed at once; but not ≈øo that which is ≈øpirituall; this is done by degrees, by little and little: He that is already dead and buried in a ≈øpirituall ≈øen≈øe, that is, he who≈øe old man, who≈øe imbred corruption is as it were put to death, and laid in the grave, yet mu≈øt ≈øtill die in that kind, and be buried ≈øtill more and more, becau≈øe he hath ≈øtill ≈øome reliques of the old man, ≈øtill ≈øome ≈øin and corruption remains in him. The Apo≈øtle having ≈øaid, ye are dead, Col. 3. 3. Yet addes v. 3. Mortifie therefore your members which are upon the earth; fornication, uncleanne≈ø≈øe, &c.

But let us con≈øider this; we profe≈ø≈øe our ≈øelves Chri≈øtians, Di≈øciples, and followers of Chri≈øt, and ≈øo con≈øequently dead and buried with him. If then we walk in ≈øin, we make our ≈øelves prodigious: for is it not a prodigious thing for one that is dead and buried, yet to walk as if he were alive? O then as we have put on Chri≈øt by profe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øo at lea≈øt all that are baptized into Christ, have put on Chri≈øt, Gal. 3. 27. Let us al≈øo put on Chri≈øt by imitation, conforming our ≈øelves unto him, and walking as he walked. Of this putting on of Chri≈øt the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaks, and to it he exhorts ≈øaying, Let us walk honestly as in the day, not in rioting and in drunkenne≈ø≈øe, not in cha ‚Ä¢ bering and wantonne≈ø≈øe, not in strife and envy; but put ye on the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and make no provi≈øion for the fle≈øh to fulfill the lusts thereof, Rom. 13. 13, 14.

V≈øe 4. In the la≈øt place, the doctrine of Chri≈øts
burying may ≈øerve for our information. As 1. That it is a Chri≈øtian cour≈øe to bury the dead: Nature it ≈øelf doth teach ≈øo much, and much more Chri≈øtianity, that the dead ought to be buried. The Saints have ≈øhewed a ≈øpeciall care to perform their duty in this re≈øpect. Sarah being dead, Abraham was very carefull to have her buried. I am a ≈øtranger and a ≈øojourner with you (≈øaid he to the Hittites) give me a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a burying place with you, that I may bury my dead out of my ≈øight, Gen. 23. 4. And it is ob≈øervable, that he purcha≈øed nothing in the Land of Canaan, but only the place there ≈øpoken of to bury in. So Stephen being ≈øtoned to death, devout men carried him to be buried, Act. 8. 2. It's recorded of I≈øaac and I≈ømael, that when Abraham their Father was dead, they buried him, Gen. 25. 9. And ≈øo of Iacob and E≈øau, that they did the ≈øame for I≈øaac, Gen. 35. 29. Though I≈ømael and E≈øau were prophane per≈øons (Gal. 4. 29. Heb. 12. 16.) yet they joyned with I≈øaac and Jacob, who were godly, in the burying of their Father: that therefore which we read in the Go≈øpell, that when Chri≈øt called one to follow him, and he de≈øired fir≈øt to go and bury his Father, Chri≈øt ≈øaid, Let the dead bury the dead; That, I ≈øay, is not ≈øo to be taken, as if Chri≈øt did condemn, or vilifie the office of burying the dead, as if this care did not become the godly. For (as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith in another1 Tim. 5. ‚Ä¢ . ca≈øe) He that neglects this, hath denied the faith, and is wor≈øe then an infidell, becau≈øe he omits that which even infidells will be carefull to perform: But it was only the intent and meaning of Chri≈øt, to teach that all carnall affections mu≈øt be laid a≈øide,
and nothing mu≈øt hinder us from following Chri≈øt, when he doth call, nor from doing that which he doth enjoyn. How far Chri≈øt was from intending to di≈øparage the office of burying the dead, may appear by that which he ≈øpake in defence of Mary, whom ≈øome excepted again≈øt, becau≈øe of the precious ointment that ≈øhe had powred upon him, ≈øaying, that it might better have been ≈øold, and the money given to the poor, Let her alone (≈øaid Chri≈øt) for again≈øt the day of my burying hath ≈øhe done this, Joh. 12. 7. They are therefore inhumane, who not content with the death of tho≈øe whom they hate and per≈øecute, wil not ≈øuffer them to be buried, or not to re≈øt when they are buried. This indeed is a puni≈øhment denounced again≈øt, and inflicted upon ≈øome for the example of others. He ≈øhall be buried with the buriall of an a≈ø≈øe, drawn and cast forth beyond the gates of Jeru≈øalem, Jer. 22. 19. Their dead bodies ≈øhal be for meat to the fowls of the heaven, and to the beasts of the earth, Jer. 32. 20. And as Jo≈øiah turned him≈øelf, he e≈øpied the Sepulchers that were there in the mount, and he ≈øent and took the bones out of the Sepulchers, and burnt them upon the Altar, &c. 2 King. 23. 16. God had long before declared, that Jo≈øiah ≈øhould thus deal with the dead bones of Idolaters, 1 Kings 13. 2. But what doth this make for them, who deal thus even with the Saints, who≈øe death is precious in the ≈øight of the Lord? This the P≈øalmi≈øt complains ≈øore of, The dead bodies of thy ≈øervants have they given to be meat to the fowls of the heavens, the fle≈øh of thy Saints unto the bea≈øts of the earth. Their blood have
they ≈øhed like water round about Ieru≈øalem, and there was none to bury them, P≈øal. 79. 2, 3. Thus barbarou≈øly did they of the Romi≈øh Church here in the time of Q. Mary deal with tho≈øe worthy men Bucer and Fagius, they digged up their dead bodies out of their graves, and con≈øumed them in the fire: and this inhumanity have ≈øome u≈øed towards the dead, out of a de≈øire to revenge them≈øelves on them to the uttermo≈øt; as it is ≈øaid of Sylla, that he cau≈øed the dead body of Marius his adver≈øary to be digged up. And ≈øo Pope Sergius the third is reported to have dealt in like manner with his Predece≈ø≈øour Formo≈øus, whom he hated, becau≈øe he had gotten the Papal dignity before him.

2. From Chri≈øts burying, we may learn that the cu≈øtome of the Country (having nothing ≈øuper≈øtitious, nor uncomely in it) is in this re≈øpect to be ob≈øerved: It is ≈øaid that for the manner of Chri≈øts burying, it was as the manner of the Iews was to bury Joh. 19. 40. Whence Au≈øtin ob≈øerves, that in tho≈øe offices In huju≈ømodi officiis, quae mortuis exhibentur, mos ‚Ä¢ uju≈ølibet regionis e≈øt ≈øervandus. Aug. that are performed to the dead, the cu≈øtome of each Countrey is to be ob≈øerved.

Caution. But concerning buriall, this caution is requi≈øite, not to think any therefore more aliens from Chri≈øt, if they be not buried at all, or but meanly buried; nor therefore to think any the nearer unto Chri≈øt, if they have a ≈øumptuous and ≈øtately buriall. The Papi≈øts are very ≈øuper≈øtitious in this, thinking it to concern the welfare of the ≈øoul, to be buried rather in one
place then in another. Purgatory is the ground of this conceit, but Purgatory it ≈øelf hath no ground in Scripture for it. The Scripture tels us, that whenEccl. 12. 7. a man dies, as the body goeth to the earth, ≈øo the ≈øoul goes to God, viz. to be judged by him; neither ≈øhal the ≈øoul fare better or wor≈øe, whether the body be buried or not, or buried after this, or another manner. We read of the rich mans burying, Luk. 16. yet his ≈øoul went to hell: We read not of any buriall that Lazarus had, yet his ≈øoul was carried into Abrahams bo≈øome. True it is, the Patriarks of old were very ≈øolicitous about their burying in the Land of Canaan, though they died out of it, Gen. 47. 29, 30, 31, & 49. 29. &c. And 50. 26. But that was not out of any ≈øuper≈øtitious opinion that they had, as if the welfare of their ≈øouls did depend upon the place where they were buried, but only to ≈øhew that they died in faith, being fully a≈ø≈øured that God would at length perform what he had promi≈øed, viz. that he would give them (in their po≈øterity) the Land of Canaan: God will ≈øurely vi≈øit you, ≈øaid Jo≈øeph, ≈øpeaking of this very thing, Gen. 50. 25. And be≈øides they looked on Canaan, not as a bare earthly Countrey, but as a type of heaven. To conclude therefore, let it be our care to live and to die in faith, and then however it fare with us in re≈øpect of buriall, we are happy, our ≈øouls enter into ‚Ä¢ li≈ø≈øe immediately, 2 Cor. 5. 1. And ≈øo al≈øo ≈øhall our bodias at length be made par ‚Ä¢ akers of it, 1 Cor. 15. 53.

div.head: THE SEVENTEENTH SERMON.

epigraph.q: PSA. 16. 10. Thou wilt not leave my ≈øoul in hell.

div.p:
THe Article of Chri≈øts de≈øcending into hell, is grounded upon this Text, wherein as S. Peter ≈øhews, Act. 2. 25. &c. David ≈øpake concerning Chri≈øt. And therefore Au≈øtin mightQuis ni≈øi infidelis negaverit fui≈ø≈øe apud inferos Chri≈øtum? Aug. Epi≈øt. 99. wel ≈øay, who but an infidel wil deny that Chri≈øt was in hell? For this, that Chri≈øts ≈øoul ≈øhould not be left in hell, doth nece≈ø≈øarily pre≈øuppo≈øe that his ≈øoul was in hell: For it is mo≈øt irrational and ab≈øurd, to ≈øay that one ≈øhall be left there, where he never was, nor ≈øhould be. All therefore (as Bellarmine ob≈øerves)Omnes conveniunt, qu√≤d Chri≈øtus aliquo modo ad inferos de≈øcenderit. Bell. de Chri≈øti anima lib. 4. cap. 6. agree in this, that Chri≈øt ≈øome way, in one ≈øen≈øe or other, was in hell. But for the manner how Chri≈øt was in hell, there is much difference among Divines; and all ari≈øes from the word hell, which ≈øome take in one ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øome in another, I ≈øhall as briefly, and per≈øpicuou≈øly as I
may ≈øet down the ≈øeveral opinions, that there are about this point, confuting tho≈øe which I hold to be erroneous, and confirming that which I judge to be true.

Fir≈øt therefore, becau≈øe the word Hell is ≈øometimesThe fir≈øt opinion about Chri≈øts de≈øcending into hell. in Scripture u≈øed metaphorically, for mo≈øt great & grievous affliction, which is indured here in this life, (the ≈øorrows of hell compa≈ø≈øed me about, ≈øaies David, P≈øal. 18. 5. So P≈øal. 116. 3. The pains of hell got hold on me.) Some by Chri≈øts de≈øcending into hell ≈øpoken of in the Creed, under≈øtand the inward ≈øufferings of Chri≈øts ≈øoul, which of all his ≈øufferings were mo≈øt grievous. But to omit other arguments again≈øt this opinion, it is ≈øufficiently overthrown by this, that the≈øe words of David (Thou wilt not leave my ≈øoul in hell) as cited and expounded by Peter in the ≈øecond of the Acts, are the ground of that Article in the Creed; for el≈øe it hath no ground in Scripture, as I think I am ≈øure, there is no place which doth ≈øo clearly hold out unto us by nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence Chri≈øts being in hell, as this doth. And therefore though Calvin, (a prime Author of this fir≈øt opinion, and a man mo≈øt de≈øervedly renowned in the Church of God) ≈øpake con≈øentaneou≈øly to his opinion, when in his Commentary upon this ≈øixteenth P≈øalm, he liked not that upon occa≈øion of the≈øe words of David, any ≈øhould fall upon the point of Chri≈øts de≈øcending into hell, which is mentioned in the Creed, yet I can by no means a≈ø≈øent unto him. For if not the≈øe words of David which we have now in hand, no place in all the Scripture (I dare ≈øay) will afford occa≈øion to treat of the Article. But it
appears that Calvin (being a man very acute) did well perceive that the≈øe words of David, Thou wilt not leave my ≈øoul in hell, as commented upon Act. 2. will not admit, that Chri≈øts de≈øcending into hell ≈øhould be expounded of the ≈øufferings of Chri≈øts ≈øoul. For by hell in the words of David, mu≈øt needs be meant ≈øomething that concerned Chri≈øt when he was dead: Peter tells us that in tho≈øe words (Thou wilt not leave my ≈øoul in hell) David ≈øpake of the Re≈øurrection of Chri≈øt, Act. 2. 31. Now if this, that Chri≈øts ≈øoul ≈øhould not be left in hell, import that Chri≈øt ≈øhould ri≈øe from the dead, then it mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily follow, that Chri≈øts being in hell, which is implied in Davids words, imports ≈øomething that concerned him being dead: And con≈øequently the ≈øufferings of Chri≈øts ≈øoul, which were before his death, cannot be meant by it.

Secondly, the Papi≈øts take hell here for Limbus The ≈øecond opinion. Patrum, as they call it, a place where they ≈øay the ≈øouls of the godly that died before Chri≈øt, were. For they divide hell into four ≈øeverall regions, 1. The hell of the damned, the place of eternall torment, 2. Purgatory, where they ≈øay the ≈øouls of ≈øuch are as were not ≈øufficiently purged from their ≈øins, whiles they were upon earth, and therefore for the thorough purging of them, are there in torment equall for the time to that of the damned, 3. Limbus Infantium, a place where they place ≈øuch Infants as die without bapti≈øme, whom they make to ≈øuffer the lo≈ø≈øe of heaven and heavenly happine≈ø≈øe, but no pain or torment, 4. Limbus Patrum, where in like manner the Fathers
before Chri≈øt (as they hold) were, ≈øuffering no pain, but only wanting the joys of heaven. To that place (≈øay they) did Chri≈øts ≈øoul when it was ≈øeparated from his body, de≈øcend, to deliver the ≈øouls from thence, and to carry them to heaven; this is their opinion, and their expo≈øition of the Article of Chri≈øts de≈øcending into hell.

But not now to conte≈øt with them about tho≈øe other regions of hell, viz. Purgatory and Limbus Infantium, as for this Limbus Patrum, it is a place of their own devi≈øing, we ≈øee no ground for it in Scripture, but ≈øtrong rea≈øons again≈øt it. For 1. Chri≈øts death was efficacious to believers before his coming, as well as it is now ≈øince his coming. Je≈øus Chri≈øt ye≈øterday, and to day, and the ≈øame for ever, Heb. 13. 8. We believe that thorough the grace of our Lord Je≈øus Christ, we ≈øhall be ≈øaved even as they, ≈øaid Peter, ≈øpeaking of tho≈øe that were before Chri≈øt. He doth but equall us to them in point of ≈øalvation thorough Chri≈øt.

2. The faithfull before Chri≈øt did account this life upon earth a pilgrimage, and did expect heaven as their country, when this life was ended. The≈øe all died in faith (it is ≈øpoken of Abraham I≈øaac and Jacob) having not received the promi≈øes (that is, the things promi≈øed) but ≈øaw them afar off, and were per≈øwaded of them, and embraced them, and confe≈ø≈øed that they were ≈øtrangers and pilgrims on the earth. For they that ≈øay ≈øuch things, declare plainly that they ≈øeek a Countrey. And truly if they had been mindfull of that country, from whence they came out, they might have had opportunity to have returned. But now they de≈øire a better country, that
is, an heavenly; wherefore God is not a≈øhamed to be called their God, for he hath prepared for them a City, Heb. 11. 11. 14, 15, 16.

3. Abrahams bo≈øome (as the place is called, where the ≈øouls of the godly were before Chri≈øt) could be no ≈øuch place as that which they call Limbus Patrum. For 1. Lazarus was carried thither by Angels, Luk. 16. 22. But Angels (the good Angels, as they were) ≈øhould rather carry to heaven then to hell, as they make their Limbus to be. 2. It was a place of comfort, Luk. 16. 25. But where hellNondum inveni, & adhuc quaero, nec mihi occurit Inferos alicubi in bono po≈øui≈ø≈øe Scripturam duntaxat Canonicam, non autem in bono accipiendum ≈øinum Abrahae, & illam requiem, qu√≤ ab angelis pius pauper ablatus e≈øt, ne≈øcio utr√πm qui≈øquam po≈ø≈øit audire. Aug. de Gen. ad lit. l. 12. c. 33. in Scripture is taken for a place of comfort, let them look: Augu≈øtine confe≈ø≈øeth that he did ≈øeek, but could not find it; and thought this a good argument, why by hell ≈øhould not be meant Abrahams bo≈øom. 3. There was a great ≈øpace, a great gulfe betwixt the place called Abrahams bo≈øome where Lazarus was, and the place of torment where the rich man was, Luk. 16. 26. Whence al≈øo Austin inferreth that Abrahams bo≈øome is no part, and as it were a memberIn his ip≈øis tanti magi≈øtri verbis, ubi ait dixi≈ø≈øe Abraham, Inter vos & nos Chaos magnum firmatum est, ≈øatis, ut opinor, ipparet, non e≈ø≈øe quandam partem, & qua≈øi membrum inferorum tantae illius faelicitatis ≈øinum. Aug. Epist. 99. Jan≈øen. Concord. cap. 97. of hell, which the Papi≈øts make it to be. Jan≈øenius a learned Papi≈øt (being much more ingenious then Bellarmine, and Gregory Martin, who would gladly fa≈øten upon Au≈øtin that which is quite contrary to his meaning) confe≈ø≈øeth that Au≈øtin by di≈øcour≈øe and argumentation
did gather, that Abrahams bo≈øome was no part of hell; neither doth he, nor any other that I know, indeavour to an≈øwer the rea≈øons that induced Austine to be of this judgement.

4. Chri≈øt promi≈øed to the believing thief, ≈øaying, This day ≈øhalt thou be with me in Paradi≈øe. Now Bellarmine him≈øelfe (handling another Bellar. de Beatitud. Sanct. l. 1. c. 3. point) holds Paradi≈øe there to be heaven, as the word is u≈øed; 2 Cor. 12. 4. compared with v. 2. Now how doth this ≈øtand with that a≈ø≈øertion of theirs, that the ≈øouls of the Saints were not in heaven untill Chri≈øts a≈øcen≈øion? or that Chri≈øts ≈øoul went to Limbus, a place very farre di≈øtant and different from heaven? Some ≈øay, that the Thief to whom Chri≈øt ≈øpake, de≈øcended with Chri≈øt into Limbus, and that it was then Paradi≈øe when Chri≈øt was there: But this (as a reverend Author ≈øaith well) B. ∆≤≈øher of Chri≈øts de≈øcent into hell. Bellar. de beat. Sanc. l. 1. c. 6. is to turn the third heaven into the third or fourth hell.

5. Bellarmine proves that the faithfull now ≈øince the coming of Chri≈øt; go immediately after death to heaven, (except Purgatory ≈øtop them a while) and that becau≈øe God is not more prone and ready to puni≈øh, then he is to reward; therefore ≈øeeing the wicked go immediately to hell, there is no rea≈øon to conceive but that the godly go immediately to heaven. And that the wicked when they die go immediately to hell, he proves by the example of the rich man mentioned Luk. 16. Now if this argument be of force, (as I grant it is) then it proves as much for the faithfull that were before Chri≈øt: For that of the rich man, Luk. 16. ≈øhewes that then (before
Chri≈øts death) the wicked immediately after death went to hell, where the damned are in torment; and neither will the Papi≈øts however deny that. And therefore why ≈øhould they deny that the godly then did go immediately to heaven, God being no le≈ø≈øe ready to reward, then to puni≈øh? The≈øe rea≈øons there are again≈øt that Limbus which they ≈øpeak of, and ≈øo again≈øt their Expo≈øition of the Article of Chri≈øts de≈øcending into hell: But ≈øome Objections they make, which are to be an≈øwered.

Object. They object that Gen. 37. 53. I will go down to the grave (to hell, as they read it) to my Son, &c. Thus ≈øpake Iacob concerning his ≈øon Jo≈øeph, when his brethren had ≈øold him, and made Jacob believe that ≈øome wild bea≈øt had devoured him. The Hebrew word there u≈øed viz. Sheol, which we ≈øometimes tran≈ølate grave, ≈øomtimes hell, they ≈øay cannot there ≈øignifie grave, but mu≈øt ≈øignifie hell, viz. that part of hell, which they call Limbus Patrum; Jacobs meaning (≈øay they) was that he would go mourning thither, whither Jo≈øeph (as he ≈øuppo≈øed) was gone before him: And they prove that the grave cannot there be meant, becau≈øe Jacob imagined Io≈øeph torne in pieces by ≈øome wild bea≈øt, and ≈øo not to have been buried.

An≈øw. But this place makes nothing for their purpo≈øe; all that Iacob meant was, that in vain did they go about to comfort him, for he would not be comforted, but would mourn unto death, even as Jo≈øeph (he thought) was dead: It's not unu≈øuall for tho≈øe that mourn for their friends
being dead, to ≈øay that they will go unto them, Aben Ezrae a Jewi≈øh Rabbin doth upon that very place Gen. 37. 33. reprove them that take Sheol for hell. See B. U≈øher of Chri≈øts de≈øcent. meaning that they al≈øo will die as they died: As for the word Sheol, it ≈øignifies the e≈øtate of the dead, (as hereafter I ≈øhall ≈øhew) and ≈øo the grave, yet not properly an artificiall grave, but a naturall grave, ≈øuch an one as nature one way or other doth provide for every one, what≈øoever the manner of his death be. It's reported of the Hyrcanians, that they were ≈øo barbarous, as to ca≈øt dead bodies unto doggs to be devoured: And that thereupon Diogenes u≈øed to ≈øay, that if he were torne in pieces by dogs, yet he ≈øhould have an Hyrcanian buriall; ≈øo if Io≈øeph had been devoured by a wild bea≈øt, the very belly of the bea≈øt had been a grave unto him.
Object. But again, they object likewi≈øe that Joh. 14. 2. I go to prepare a place for you; thence they infer, that before Chri≈øts a≈øcen≈øion none did go to heaven.

div.p:
V≈øe 5. FIftly and la≈øtly, as Chri≈øt ro≈øe corporally, ≈øo ought we to ri≈øe ≈øpiritually, viz. from the death of ≈øin, to the life of grace.
